section.title: Cofactor expansions
section.p: We now give another description of the determinant which is often useful in computations.

This is called the cofactor expansion of a matrix, and computes the determinant from the ground up via a recursive procedure. Namely, this method will show how to compute the determinant for n\times n matrices, assuming we already know how to do so for (n-1)\times(n-1) matrices.

Let's start at the beginning. First, we consider the case of 1\times1 matrices. The definition of determinant directly implies that \det\mat a=a. To describe cofactor expansions, we first need to introduce a little notation.

statement.p: Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix A.
The (i,j)-th minor, denoted A_{ij}, is the (n-1)\times (n-1) matrix obtained from A by deleting the i-th row and the j-th column.
The (i,j)-th cofactor \ C_{ij} is defined in terms of the minor by C_{ij}=(-1)^{i+j}\det A_{ij}.

section.p: Using , we can describe our procedure for computing determinants as follows.

algorithm.title: Cofactor/Laplace expansion
algorithm.p:
To compute the determinant of a square matrix, do the following.
Choose any row or column of A.
For each element a_{ij} of this row or column, compute the associated cofactor C_{ij}.
Multiply each cofactor by the associated matrix entry a_{ij}.
Result: The sum of these products is \det A.

section.p: In formulas, this says that if we pick row i to "expand along," then the cofactor expansion formula is \det A=\sum_{j=1}^n a_{ij}C_{ij}, where in the sum the number i is fixed. Similarly, if we pick column j to expand along, then we obtain a formula \det A=\sum_{i=1}^n a_{ij}C_{ij}. Note that this gives 2n seemingly-different formulas, which all give the same number! We will see why this is true later, and simply assume this for now.
Let's try this out for a general 2\times2 matrix A=\mat{a b;c d}. The minors are computed as follows:
In the next example, we use cofactor expansion find a formula for the determinant of any 3\times 3 matrix.
Here we perform the computation for a particular matrix.

statement.p: We find the determinant of A= \mat{2 1 3;-1 2 1;-2 2 3}. We make the somewhat arbitrary choice to expand along the first row. We compute the minors as A_{11} = \mat{2 1;2 3} \quad\quad A_{12}=\mat{-1 1;2 3} \quad\quad A_{13}=\mat{-1 2;-2 2}. Computing these 2\times 2 determinants, we have \det A_{11}=4,\quad\quad \det A_{12}=-1,\quad\quad \det A_{13}=2. By inserting signs, we find that the cofactors are C_{11}=\det A_{11}=4,\quad\quad C_{12}=-\det A_{12}=1,\quad\quad C_{13}=\det A_{13}=2. Thus, \det A=a_{11}C_{11}+a_{12}C_{12}+a_{13}C_{13} =2(4)+(1)+3(2)=15.

section.p: With this method, much larger determinants are also easy to compute, especially when there are lots of zeros in a row or column. Generally speaking, it is a good idea when computing an example to try to expand along a row or column with as many zeros as possible, or at least with the smallest entries possible.

Although this technique works reasonably quickly in most small examples, several questions come to mind.
Where do these formulas come from?
How do we know that these numbers give the same answer regardless of which row or column we choose (that is, this method gives 2n different expressions for the same number attached to an n\times n matrix, which we claim are always all equal).
How do we know that this procedure gives the same number as in the definition of determinant by row reduction in the last section?
For now, we don't have the tools to answer these questions. However, these "coincidences" show that the existence of a function like the determinant is surprising and very special.
